newsitem.title: USA: CBOT board backs exchange stand on delivery points.
newsitem.headline: CBOT board backs exchange stand on delivery points.

text.p: The Board of Directors of the Chicago Board of Trade re-affirmed its support of controversial corn and soybean delivery location changes, the exchange said in a release issued Thursday.

At a special board meeting held Wednesday, the directors also voted against proceeding with an interim plan proposed by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission that would reinstate Toledo as a delivery point.

The proposal, approved by the membership last month by a two-to-one margin, established delivery points along the Illinois River from Pekin, Ill., to Chicago, including Burns Harbor, Ind. It eliminated delivery at Toledo.
The plan has drawn fire, largely from eastern Corn Belt producers, merchants and politicians. Hundreds of opponents have sent letters to the CFTC which is reviewing the proposal.

"In essence, the CFTC asked the CBOT to abandon the proposal that was thoughtfully prepared by a knowledgeable task force and overwhelmingly approved by our membership," CBOT Chairman Pat Arbor said in a release.
"The exchange remains committed to our proposal because it is the best alternative overall for U.S. agriculture and the U.S. economy. We will not bow to the pressures of narrow self-interests."
A spokesman for the CFTC said the agency had no comment on the exchange's latest action.
"This is a proposal still out for public comment. We'll go through the usual process and analyze the comments when the period ends June 16," the spokesman said.
